In this section, as an exercise, we are going to write a simple rule that removes affixes from words of a certain category. We’ll modify an existing rule to do this.

ol.li: Navigate to the 'lFlexTools\Output folder in your installation folder.
Open the file transfer_rules.t1x in . It should look something like . This is the transfer rules file that works with the sample projects.
Expand the rule element and also the output element so that it looks like .
Pick a category that you are going to process. In this example let’s use noun, abbreviated “n”.
Change the rule comment shown in blue to “Nouns”
Change the item element to “c_n”. This means category noun. This changes the pattern to match nouns. Nouns get defined below.
Remove the two literal tag elements by clicking on the word “literal” and pressing the delete key. The rule should now look like .
Expand the Categories element and the second category element and it should look like .

Change “c_v” to “c_n” in the category element and “v” to “n” in both tags elements. Now it should look something like . Category “c_n” is now defined as the single tag “n” or the tag “n” followed by any other tag, i.e. affixes and the like.
Expand the Attributes element and the second attribute element and it should look like . Note that we already have a tag for a noun.
We are done editing the rule. You can save the file.

section2.p: In brief what this rule does is set up an action to take place when a word is processed by the Apertium engine that has the “n” tag. (Every word coming from has the word’s grammatical category in the form of a tag.)

The action that gets executed is to basically strip off any affixes from the word. This is accomplished by outputting the word itself -- the “lem” part and the grammatical category -- anything that matches a tag specified by in the “a_gram_cat” attribute. No affixes are explicitly outputted. The target lang. attribute of the clip elements in above is selected so the target word that corresponds to the input source word is outputted.

The authoritative reference document for transfer rules is found in section 3.5 and appendix 3 of . intro info here (not sure if would be helpful) http://wiki.apertium.org/wiki/Apertium_New_Language_Pair_HOWTO#Transfer_rules

The is a tool that allows you to test source words or sentences live against transfer rules. This tool is especially helpful for finding out why transfer rules not are doing what you expect them to do. You can zero in on the problem by selecting just one source word and applying the pertinent transfer rule. In this way you don’t have to run the whole system against the whole text file and all transfer rules. Here’s sample screen shot of the :

section2.p: Here’s a quick guide on using the tool.

ol.li: First you want to choose something from your source text that you want to test. When you first run the tool, the words of the first sentence are shown both in the drop down list at the top and in the peach colored area. You can check one or more words and when you do the data stream format of the words is shown in the blue colored area. You can quickly select a whole sentence, by clicking on the Select Sentences tab and clicking the check box for the sentence you want.

Next select which rule or rules you want to run against the words you selected. Check the check boxes in the purple area as appropriate. Check them all with the Select All button. Uncheck them all with the Refresh button. Move a rule up or down by clicking on it and clicking the up or down arrow buttons.
Now you are ready to test. Click the Test button and the selected works will get processed. The results will show in data stream format in the green colored area.
Check the yellow Information box. It will show which words were matched for the rules that were executed.

section1.secTitle: The Set Up Transfer Rule Grammatical Categories Tool
section1.p: The Set Up Transfer Rule Grammatical Categories Tool is a tool that will put the necessary attribute values for grammatical categories into your transfer rules file. Every transfer rule will likely need to reference the grammatical category of a word either in the source or target language. The initial transfer rules file that comes with has just a few sample grammatical categories. This tool will take the categories that are in the bilingual lexicon file and insert them as tags under the specific attribute called a_gram_cat in the transfer rules file. The list of grammatical categories will be a complete list of all the unique categories in both the source and target projects.

You should only need to run this tool one time at the beginning of the project. If new grammatical categories get added to either project, you could delete the a_gram_cat attribute and run this tool again to get an updated list in your transfer rules file.

section1.secTitle:
A Tutorial on Writing Transfer Rules
For this tutorial I am basically reproducing the Apertium article A long introduction to transfer rules. I am mainly modifying it to show the method of editing the transfer rules, but also the process is assumed instead of the Apertium process.
section1.p: Writing transfer rules is not as tricky as it might seem. People generally understand the basic concepts, but they sometimes struggle with the formalism. Maybe one of the reasons people struggle is that the formalism mixes declarative and procedural statements. This tutorial should help you get used to writing transfer rules.

section3.secTitle: Some Formalities
section3.p: Before starting, it is important to get an idea of what we can’t do, before explaining what we can.

ul.li: There are no recursive rules. Rules match fixed-length patterns. There is no optionality at the level of words. There is no way of saying one or more, it’s just one.

Rules contain both declarative parts and procedural parts. You can’t just expect to say what you want or how you want to do it. You need to do both -- but in different places (but it’s quite intuitive).
Patterns match only on the source side, not on the target side.

The transfer process has no access to the information in the target language dictionary. This means that if the transfer needs some information about the available forms of a particular word, e.g. if it is only singular, or only plural, then this information needs to go in the bilingual dictionary.

section3.secTitle: Approaching the Process of Writing Transfer Rules
section3.p: Think bottom up, not top down. Start with a question like “What is the simplest and best equivalent for dative in a language which does not have dative?” not “How can I change SOV order to SVO order?”

section3.secTitle: Lexical Transfer and Structural Transfer
section3.p: We don't want to confuse the roles of lexical transfer and structural transfer. There is a grey area between the two, but there are also big parts that don’t overlap.

ul.li:
Lexical transfer (the bilingual.dix file -- produced by the and the Extract Bilingual Lexicon module)
Nearly always gives translations between words, not tags.
Can add or change tags, on a per-sense basis.
Doesn’t do reordering.
Can be used to give a head’s up to the structural transfer to draw attention to missing features, or features that cannot be decided on a no-context basis.

Structural transfer (the transfer_rules.t1x file -- edited with )
Rarely gives translations between single words.
Often adds or changes tags on a per-category (groups of words) basis.
Can change the order of words.

section3.p: A rule-of-thumb is, if the rule applies to all words in a category, it probably wants to be treated in the structural transfer; if it applies to just part of those words, then maybe it needs to be dealt with in the lexical transfer.

Lexical transfer looks like . In other words, the bilingual dictionary maps a source word to target word. In we don’t see the source and target lexical units together like this, but under the hood this is what it is.

single.langData:
slword1.1 somecat -> tlword1.1 somecat
slword12.1 somecat blah -> tlword31.2 somecat foo
slword33.1 somecat blah -> tlword21.1 somecat GD

section3.p: The output of the structural transfer would look like .

single.langData: tlword1.1 somecat tlword31.2 somecat foo tlword21.1 somecat GD

section3.p: When you are in the structural transfer stage, you have access to both the source and target sides of the translation.

section3.secTitle: Some Preliminaries
section3.p:
The transfer rule file is written in an XML format and in it is named transfer_rules.t1x
The 1 in .t1x stands for the first structural transfer pass. This is the only file we worry about when doing a shallow-transfer system. For advanced-transfer, you use three rule files, and the extensions .t2x and .t3x are also used.. We could do all the editing of the transfer rules in a text editor, but by using the structured editor we not only get a graphical user interface, but also verification that the rule file we are writing is valid. In fact the and the add-ons for make it hard to write an invalid rule file.

section3.secTitle: Overview of a Transfer File
section3.p: It’s hard to give a step-by-step overview of what a transfer file looks like because there is quite a lot of obligatory parts that need to go into even the most basic file. But, it’s important to get a general view before we go into the details. Here is an example in which I’m deliberately not going to use linguistic names for the different parts to try and avoid assumptions.
You should see this same thing when you open the file transfer_rules.t1x (FLExTrans Documentation\Transfer Rules Tutorial folder) in the . (Expand all the elements.)

The transfer file is divided into two main parts: a declaration section and a rules section. The rules section uses information from the declaration section. In fact, every kind of reference you make in the rules section, you have to declare in the declaration section. The rules section is clearly denoted by the element Rules. All of the elements above Rules are part of the declaration section. In a minimal amount of declarations are shown, namely the Categories, Attributes, and Variables elements. (The elements Lists and Macros are not shown.)
Rules have two main parts: the pattern definition and the actions to be carried out.

The pattern element is what determines if Apertium runs the rule or not. If the input word or words match the pattern, Apertium will run the rule. The thing that goes in the item sub-element of the pattern element is a list of one or more categories (from the declaration section) you want to match.

The action element contains the steps you want to perform in the rule, generally ending with an output element where you output lexical units into the data stream. Note how declared attributes are used in the action element. Categories and attributes are discussed more below.

section3.secTitle: How Rules are Applied
section3.p: Rules are applied when a pattern is matched in the source language input data stream. Which patterns are matched in which order goes like this: the longest patterns are attempted first and then successive shorter patterns are attempted. When there is more than one pattern of the same length, the pattern that comes first in the file is attempted first followed by the rest in order.

Patterns do not overlap. Once a pattern is matched, the matched words are processed and not considered again for any other patterns. In other words, the source language words are processed sequentially in chunks.

section3.p: For the purposes of this example, we are going to use some “pre-prepared” data. We have a Croatian text that is already analyzed and we have small Croatian and English lexicons with all of the entries and senses that we need.

section3.secTitle: Thinking it Through
section3.p: Let’s think about what changes we need to make in order to convert the output shown in into an adequate form for target language synthesis. NB: If we want to change information, it’s a procedure; if we want to output information or not output information, it’s a declaration.

ol.li:
If the source language grammatical category tag is ptcp_f_sg, change the target language tag to pst
pst corresponds to the past suffix in the English project (and also the past tense feature).
Output a subject pronoun which takes its person and number information from the auxiliary verb.
Output the main verb with information on category and tense (but not aspect).
Do not output the auxiliary verb biti, “be”.
Output nouns with their grammatical category (but not number or case).

section4.p: So, what order do we do these in? Well it doesn’t really matter. An experienced linguist would probably do it in two steps, but for pedagogical purposes, we’re going to split it up into five steps:

ul.li:
First, we’re going to write a rule which matches the participle and auxiliary construction and outputs only the main verb (declarations: 2 & 3).
Define the categories of “ptcp_f_sg” and “biti”.

Second, we’re going to edit that rule to change the source language tag from ptcp_f_sg to pst (procedure: 1).
Define the attribute of “tense”.

Third, we’re going to edit the same rule to not output aspect (declaration: 2).
Define the attribute for grammatical category and add the tag for “verb”.

Fourth, we’re going to edit the same rule to output a subject pronoun before the verb (declaration: 1).
Define the attributes of “person” and “number”.

Fifth, we’re going to write a new rule which matches the noun construction and output only the grammatical category (declaration: 4)
Define the category of “noun”.
Add the tag for nouns to the grammatical category attribute.

section4.p: Here is what the input and output data stream of each of the above steps will look like:

td.langData: Otići1.1 v pfv ptcp_f_sg biti1.1 cop prs sg 2
Otići1.1 v pfv ptcp_f_sg biti1.1 cop prs sg 2
Otići1.1 v pfv ptcp_f_sg biti1.1 cop prs sg 2
Otići1.1 v pfv ptcp_f_sg biti1.1 cop prs sg 2
Propers1.1 pro nom 2 sg leave1.1 v pst

li.p: Define the categories we need in transfer_rules.t1x. Replace the dummy Categories element with:
You may be wondering how you get a new category element inserted. It is straightforward:

ol.li: Click on the word “category”. The whole element becomes outlined in a red rectangle.
Now either right-click and choose Insert After... or click on the button (upper right side) or press Ctrl-J.
At this point a list of elements to insert shows up in the upper right pane as shown in .
Choose in this case def-cat(category) since we only need one tags element. (By the way, this insert procedure will present only valid elements that can be inserted at this point in the rules file.)

li.p: Why do we need .* in the tags elements? This is because of how the matching system for categories works. In the middle of tag sequences, a * is counted as a single tag. At the end, it is counted as any sequence of tags. So, what we have is v followed by any tag, followed by ptcp_f_sg followed by any sequence of tags.
Note: we are using the convention of starting all categories with “c_”.

ol.li:
Edit the example rule and replace the pattern as shown. Also change the rule comment to “Past Construction”.
Trick: Click in the pink area of the item element and press F11. You will get a list of possible categories that can be used in this element. The list looks like .
By using this pattern we will detect a participle followed by the auxiliary. Once detected, the rule will run.
Notice that the example rule as written outputs only the first among two lexical units as seen in (“pos: 1” means the word in position 1). We are not outputting the word in position 2. The result is that our biti1.1 word will disappear.

ol.li:
Replace the dummy attribute element with an attribute that gives possible values of the tense feature.
So, now that we’ve gotten rid of the verb “be”, we want to change the tag for tense from ptcp_f_sg to pst. This will involve using a procedure statement, explicitly telling the transfer what we want to change. But before that, we need to define which possible values our feature can take. We do this with the attribute element. Let’s call it “a_tense”. Note we are using the convention of starting all attributes with “a_”.
Add the following under the Attributes element:

Write a statement which changes the tense on the target language. This statement should go immediately after the action element and before the output element. Make sure you select the target lang. property.Trick: Click in the brown area of the part property and press F11. You will get a list of possible attributes that can be used in this element. The list looks like .(Note: the statement in will always change the target language tag to pst, even if the input is not ptcp_f_sg. This is good enough for our current example, but for a description of how conditional logic works, see .
Now test it in the . (Don’t forget to refresh the rules first!)

section4.p: The result is:
Excellent!
So far we have been outputting the whole target language lexical unit, as seen in below.

An important thing to know about lexical transfer is that any source language tags not matched in the bilingual dictionary are copied into the output on the target language side. In our case, pfv pst are the tags that get copied from source to target because, in the bilingual dictionary (bilingual.dix), otići1.1 v maps to leave1.1 v. All we need is the pst tag; we don’t need the pfv tag, so we need to declare that it should not be outputted.

ol.li:
Define the features that we want to output.
We have already defined the feature “tense”: the only remaining tag we need to output is the grammatical category, i.e. v meaning verb. So, make a new attribute element for grammatical category.

Declare which features we want to output.
So, now that we’ve got our two features defined, let’s change our output statement:
Where we previously had:Replace it with:The last two features we know, as we’ve just added them. The “lem” feature is a predefined feature which corresponds to lemma, i.e. the part before the tags. In this example it would be leave1.1. There are other predefined features, but if you remember this one and “whole” which corresponds to the whole lexical unit, you have the main ones.
Now test it in the . (Don’t forget to refresh the rules first!)

Woo! What just happened was that we magically deleted the unwanted pfv tag by not specifying that we wanted it. Tag deletion is thus not stated as tag deletion (tag → 0), but by not declaring it.
Now we should have a lexical form for “leave” which we can synthesize. Let’s give it a go:

section4.p: This looks a lot better than our initial results in . The word Left is now there correctly. It’s beyond the scope of this exercise to explain in detail how the synthesis works in this case, but the tag pst matches the feature pst on the variant form of the verb leave.
We’re getting there, now let’s move on to the next step.
To recap, our input is:

single.langData: Otići1.1 v pfv ptcp_f_sg biti1.1 cop prs sg 2

section4.p: And our current output is:

What we now need to do is take the information from the (not outputted) verb biti “be” and use it to output a personal pronoun before the verb. Remember that when we do not output something we are not deleting it. It is still there in the input, we are just choosing not to put it in the output.
The pronoun that we want to output looks like . If we get it in this form, it will synthesize into the word you.

Important: We need to remember to output the 1.1 after the word and not just propers. Even though in the target project the lexeme form is propers, automatically adds the homograph number (1 because it’s the first and only homograph) and the sense number (1 because it’s the first sense). If we mistakenly use propers instead of propers1.1, the word won’t synthesize because won’t find propers in its internal dictionary. This use of x.x after the word helps identify each unique sense in the dictionary.

ol.li:
Output a skeleton pronoun.
So, we need to take the person and number information from the verb “be”, and the rest we need to just declare to be outputted. Let’s start with outputting the string propers1.1 pro nom; we won’t worry about the 2 sg tags yet.

Insert this before our current lexical unit element.The lexical unit statement means we are outputting a word
In our target_text.aper file it puts a ^ and $ before and after the contents contained within it.. The literal string element outputs the given string of characters, and the literal tag element outputs a tag sequence
In our target_text.aper file each tag starts with a <, ends with a >.. Multiple tags are separated by a period, so in this case two tags we are outputting two tags: pro and nom. The blank space element outputs a single space character.

Define features for person and number.
The next step is to declare the features from the verb “be” to output. To do this we need to again define some features and their possible values. Add this:

We then go back to our skeleton pronoun and add the missing features.Note that we are “clipping” (copying a part of a string which matches a pattern) from position 2, i.e. the verb “be”. To be clearer, the first clip statement in makes a copy of the part of the lexical unit in position 2, on the source language side, which matches one of the patterns defined in the attribute element “a_pers” (which can be either 1, 2 or 3). If we look at the lexical transfer output, that is internally coming from the bilingual dictionary for position 2, this will become clearer:

section3.secTitle: How do I use the category element in the transfer rules?
section3.p: Lexical categories are used to group words together. The grouping can be very broad such as verbs or very specific such as pronouns with feminine suffixes. The categories are used in the pattern matching system of transfer rules.

is an example of a lexical category for indefinite nominals. The period indicates where a new tag begins. The asterisk is a wildcard indicator. It means that anything can fill that position. An asterisk at the end of the item matches one or more final tags. For example, if I have the lexical unit book1.1 n f sg, it could be precisely matched by a tags element containing n.f.sg. More generally we could match book with the tags element containing n.f.*. This would refer to all words that have the grammatical category n followed by the tag f followed by anything else, i.e. feminine nouns. defines the set of all indefinite nouns — words that have the the grammatical category n or n-irreg followed by f and optionally something else afterward.

You can use the lemma element to identify a specific word-sense. shows how the category dem_this can be defined as a word that has a grammatical category of dem and lemma this1.1 (in : headword this1 , sense 1). This might be useful when you want to match phrases containing the word this.

section3.secTitle: How do I use the attribute element in the transfer rules?
section3.p: Attributes are defined in the rule file in order to identify possible values for word characteristics. An example is shown in .

Certain words may have affixes that indicate grammatical number. defines the possible values for the number attribute as being sg (singular) or pl (plural). Like lexical categories, these refer to tags in the data stream. Attributes are used within rules to get or set values.

section3.secTitle: How does pattern matching work?
How do I delete a word from the target output? (How do I prevent a source word from being transferred to the target text?)
section3.p: The short answer is don't output it. In other words, don't declare that it should be outputted into the target data stream.

When you match two or more words in the pattern section of a transfer rule, you can choose to only list some of the words in the output section. This is exactly what we did in of the tutorial. In we only declared that the word in position 1 should be outputted.

section3.secTitle: How do I delete an affix?
section3.p: There are two methods for deleting an affix. You can either set the value for that affix (attribute) to blank or you can not declare that the affix (attribute) gets outputted.

ol.li: Method 1. Use the let element to set an attribute's value to blank. See .Here we are overriding whatever is in the enclitic attribute (a_encl) with a blank string. Whenever the enclitic affix gets outputted, it will be outputted as nothing. As an example, in the whole word is outputted with all its attributes.

Method 2. In the Output element, explicitly declare each attribute of the word that you want to output. Don't include the attribute that needs to be deleted.In you can see that the lemma is outputted and then the grammatical category and then two attribute. The disadvantage of this method is that you have to explicitly declare every possible attribute that could occur. Where as in in Method 1, you just have to output the whole word.

section3.secTitle: How so I use conditional logic in a transfer rule? (How do I say if this ... then that?)
section3.p: In the transfer rules you have the ability to use conditional logic. Please watch this video for an explanation.

section3.secTitle: How do I handle noun agreement? (How do I get a target word or words to agree with a noun?)
section3.p: One main strategy for getting words to agree with a noun, is to make sure features are assigned to the noun and then in the transfer rules make the needed adjustment to the words you output depending on what the feature values (or class values) are.
To see how to do this in a sample language pair, please watch video 1 and video 2.

If you would like to try creating the rules along with the video, please follow the instructions in the file: Readme.txt in the Doc\Agreement folder. See the file transfer_rules - solution.t1x which shows the form of the rules shown in the video.

section3.secTitle: I have a source word that maps to two different target words depending on the inflection of the source word. How do I handle that?
section3.p: You can handle this by using the replace.dix file to add additional mappings to the bilingual lexicon.

The bilingual lexicon is a mapping of source word-senses to target word-senses. There are no inflectional affixes present in the bilingual lexicon, although there could be inflectional features or classes present. An example portion of a bilingual lexicon is shown in . You can view the bilingual lexicon by double-clicking on the file bilingual.dix in the FlexTools\Output folder. Both the replace.dix and bilingual.dix files are XML files and will load automatically in .
In order to have a word map differently than what is in the bilingual lexicon, you need to add a line to the replacement file. If you double-click on replace.dix you will see something like .

The replacement file has two main sections, one for replacing default bilingual entries with ones of your choice and one section for appending new entries to the bilingual lexicon. We are interested in doing the latter. Note, we can’t edit the bilingual dictionary file directly because that gets generated automatically by .
Let's say that we want to map the past tense of the entry for lieben shown in to a different Swedish word, we change the replacement file to something like .

Let’s look closer at the last line. The left element has lieben1.1 and the “symbol” v just like the bilingual file, but it also has a new symbol PST. This is the gloss for the past suffix in German. By adding this suffix, we are telling that we are mapping the past inflection of lieben1.1 to something else. The new Swedish word is listed for the right element. Note that we also had to add two new symbol definitions so that knows what they are. Any symbols you use in a section of the replacement file, have to be defined under the Symbols element.

You also have to make a change to the configuration file (FlexTrans.config in the FlexTools folder) to signal to use the replacement file. Change the applicable line to look like this: BilingualDictReplacementFile=Output\replace.dix

section3.secTitle: How do I handle irregularly inflected variants in the target language?
section3.p: To learn how FT can handle these kind of variants, please watch this video.
The key thing in the techniques explained in the videos is to get inflectional features assigned to Irregularly Inflected Form variants that match exactly the suffixes that would normally be used.
If you would like to try doing the same thing while watching the video, please follow the instructions in the file: Readme.txt in the Doc\Irregular Form folder.

section3.secTitle: How do I handle inflectional variants in the source language?
section3.p: To learn how FT can handle these kind of variants, please watch this video.
The key thing in the techniques explained in the videos is to get inflectional features assigned to Irregularly Inflected Form variants that match exactly the suffixes that would normally be used.

If you would like to try doing the same thing while watching the video, please follow the instructions in the file: Readme.txt in the Doc\Irregular Form folder. Note: be sure to set the SourceTextName property in the configuration file to “Text2”.
